questions.question_text: A customer wants to use a client script to validate things on a form in order to make sure the submission makes sense. What type of client script would you recommend to meet this requirement?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A - as onSubmission() doesn't exist

Selected Answer: A

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
An order from the Service Catalog has been placed. Two records in the Platform are created as a result. Which two records are associated with this newly ordered item? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
A. A record of sc_req_item table
B. A record of sc_task
A and B

Selected Answer: B
This question is the same as question #288, just the wording of the question and the correct answer is different. In Question 288 they referred to clicking on Personalize List and here they refer to clicking on the Gear icon, but it's the same thing. Personalize list is the lable of the Gear icon (when you hover over the icon you can see it)

comments.content: Gear icon = Personalized list; to check, hover your mouse over the gear icon

discussion.content: B is correct but would be better stated as Click Gear Icon > Select the appropriate columns > Ok
B is correct

choices.D: Select the column to be personalized > Click Edit icon (Pencil) > Choose the options to personalize
choices.B: Click Gear Icon > Personalize window options > Select the appropriate columns
choices.C: Select the column to be personalized and right at the header > Choose the options to personalize

questions.question_text: What action will allow you to personalize layouts of columns in a list?

discussion.content:
there is no correct answer here.
Should be Service Catalog -> open records -> requests

Selected Answer: C
The question is how would you view the lists of REQUESTS, not items. Therefore the answer is C.

Selected Answer: D
Answer is D 100%. Tested in my PDI. All --> Service Catalog --> Open Records --> Items has a field called "Requests" which, you guessed it, has REQ values.
Its not C because All --> Service Catalog --> Requests does not exist.

Selected Answer: C
List of Request (REQ) is different from the list of requested item (RITM)
REQ = ALL> SERVICE CATALOG > REQUEST
RITM = ALL > SERVICE CATALOG > OPEN RECORD > ITEM

Selected Answer: D
The question mentions Requests and I initially picked C. But that path doesn't exist in the Navigator, D is the only viable path and you can see a list of Items, in the list view you can also see Requests.

Very poorly phrased question.

Selected Answer: D
D - this is how you get to open RITMs

it's not C - who looks at REQ unless its an order guide or bundle requests with multiple RITMs

Selected Answer: C
it is C. The question asked for a list of requests, not of items.

Selected Answer: C
Service Catalog > Requests is the standard navigation path to view a list of requests placed through the Service Catalog. It displays all Request [sc_request] records, including details like request numbers, requesters, and statuses.
All->Service Catalog->Open Records ->Requests. So the answer is E. None of the above.

The correct answer is C. All > Service Catalog > Requests.

When an order is placed through the Service Catalog, it generates a request record in the Request [sc_request] table. This record can be viewed under the Service Catalog application in the navigator. 

For those saying D — This navigates to catalog items, not the requests.

Selected Answer: D
it is d

Selected Answer: D
I even checked in an instance
there is no All->Service Catalog->Request
there is either All->Service Catalog->Open Records ->Requests or All->Service Catalog->Items
hence D is correct
I am defenitilty with option D, as I test this one and request new order and I see it under Service Catalog > open record, items,

The question asks how to view the list of requests. This is C, and yes, it should have stated:
 Service Catalog -> Open records -> Requests

Selected Answer: D
C doesn't even exsit what is wrong with the vote?

comments.content: No, their is under Service Catalog - Open recodrs then items

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is the answer because there is no - All>Service Catalog>Open Record>Items

Selected Answer: D
There is no All > Service Catalog > Request...
There's All > Service Catalog > Open > List 
These also All > Service Catalog > Open > Request

Selected Answer: C
Due to the question specifying "request" and not "item" C would be the correct answer. There's the Request(REQ#)>Requested Item(RITM#). Since they're two individual records C makes sense to be the correct answer.

Selected Answer: D
I would have to go with D. 
 I am surprised by people saying they've tested C and it's the correct answer, as C doesn't even exist. There’s NO All -> Service Catalog -> Requests.
Now there is All -> Service Catalog -> Request Overview, but 1. it's not the same as C answer as it's Reuest Overview, not requests and 2. it's a Dashboard. On it you can review report widgets on request items by stages and open request items, etc. But they are in report types like Pies and Donuts, etc. Not what the question is asking for.
It's C, I just tested it in my PDI. D is the list of requested items (RITM), C views REQ.

Selected Answer: C
D views the list of requested items, while C views the list of requests, which is what the question is asking for, and therefore correct.

Selected Answer: D
D is the correct answer
I think the answer should be C because D is for items not requests. There can be multiple items in a request. To look at the requests not items, wouldn't the correct answer bc C?
D is the correct answer
D is the correct answer
D is the correct answer

Selected Answer: D
It makes more sense.
D is correct.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct. Just tested it in my Dev instance.

questions.question_text: An order for new office equipment has been placed through the Service Catalog. How would you view the lists of requests after the orders have been placed?

choices.B: In the Navigation Filter, type “requests.list" and press the Enter key
choices.D: All > Service Catalog > Open Records > Items

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Which path would you take to access the table configuration page from a form?

choices.B: The Form Context menu > View > Table
choices.D: The Form Context menu > Configure > Table
choices.A: The Form Context menu > View > Show Table
choices.C: The Form Context menu > Configure > Dictionary

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct.
